prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: First Tuning
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: first of the five tunings for the spectral scan.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We choose a combination of spectral resolution and spectral average that leads to a final resolution of roughly 5 km/s. This is sufficient for resolving the line profile even for the most narrow line (~20 km/s) in the z~5-6 [CII] detections in Capak et al. (2015).

The source has a size of ~1 arcsec in the HST images (Fig. 1). Based on the HST images, some groups argue that the source consists of two interacting galaxies. We do not expect the size of [CII] emission to be larger than the size in the HST images. For our detection experiment, we request a resolution of 0.75 arcsec for a sensitivity consideration. However, this angular resolution and the requested senstivity will be enough to show a velocity gradient (if exits) to help to determine the nature of the velocity gradient (single rotating disk vs. interacting galaxies).

NOTE: The technical justifications for the five science goals are identical. However, because of the differences in frequencies, the corresponding [CII] redshifts and expected line fluxes are slightly different, leading to slightly different sensitivity requirements. The redshifts, line fluxes, and required rms sensitivities of the five tunings are quoted in the brackets []. To allow for different sensitivity requirements for different frequencies, we set up the five tunings independently and do not rely on the non-standard spectral scan mode.
We will use five different tunings (one per science goal) to search for a [CII] emission line from z~7 (see Fig. 4). Together, the five science goals will cover the frequency range of 222 to 255 GHz. In the central 235-241 GHz region, the effective integration will be twice that in each individual science goal, providing enhanced sensitivity. However, we base our sensitivity estiamte on each individual tuning.
In the Scientific Justification, we discussed the expected [CII] line luminosity, which is 2.7e8 Lsun. With Baseband-2 as the representative windows, the corresponding redshifts of the five tunings are z = [7.460, 7.334, 7.211, 7.092, 6.976]. With the current cosmological parameters, these translate to integrated line intensities of [200.5, 205.4, 210.4, 215.5, 220.7] mJy km/sec.
In Capak et al. (2015), the [CII]-detected galaxies at z=5-6 have line widths (FWHM) of around 200 km/s. Here we assume a slightly larger line width of 300 km/s, because our source might involve two interacting galaxies.
The exact line profle of this source is unknown. It could be centrally peaked, or has a typical double-horn profile for a rotating disk. Here we assume a flat profile. This leads to line intensities of [668.2, 684.7, 701.4, 718.4, 735.6] uJy over the assumed 300 km/s width. We request a solid 6-sigma detection over this 300 km/s range. This S/N is required to identify a line in the broad spectral coverage. This leads to required rms of [111.4, 114.1, 116.9, 119.7, 122.6] uJy. We note that if the line is centrally peaked, the S/N would be even higher after line-fitting. For example, for a Gaussian line with a 300 km/s FWHM, the optimally measured S/N will increase by approximately 1.6x. The observed S/N will also be higher if the line width is more similar to the [CII] detections in Capak et al. (2015), where the FWHMs are around 200 km/s.
We do not have an expected continuum flux, as the nature of IR luminosity and dust obscuration at z~7 is unclear. The input continuum flux density of 30 uJy simply reflects the 3-sigma detection limit in continuum after we combine all the five science goals. This is very deep and sensitive enough to detect a galaxy of 5 Msun/yr of obscured star formation rate. This star formation rate is comparable to the lower-bound of the star formation rate derived from the near-IR data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent ALMA observations have successfully pushed the detections of [CII] from normal star-forming galaxies to z ~ 5-6. Here we propose to further push this into the epoch of reionization (EOR). We will conduct sensitive Band-6 observations to detect the [CII] and far-IR continuum from a carefully chosen z ~ 7 Lyman-break galaxy in the HUDF. The galaxy is unanimously agreed by many groups to be at z ~ 7. It is among the brightest z ~ 7 galaxies and has a star formation rate of up to 110 Msun/yr. It is thus the best candidate to host strong [CII] emission. Its morphology shows hint of galactic interaction. Our observing strategy does not only provide the sensitivity to detect the [CII] line, but also the frequency coverage to encompass any potential redshift uncertainties and velocity offsets between its Ly-alpha and [CII] lines. Our ALMA observations will pin down its redshift and reveal the potentially very interesting kinematics. The [CII] and far-IR continuum results will allow us to test the dust properties, obscured star formation, and the nature of UV extinction in this galaxy. These will lead to a better understanding of the sources of the ionizing photons in the EOR.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
